events.name: Future Fridays Goes to MakerFaire: Sure or Not?
events.description:
Have you ever looked back on a decision you made and wondered, "oh! Why did I believe that?"

What if we can prevent regret by training ourselves to make better decisions? What if we can help others be more aware of the biases and pitfalls that affect our personal and national decisionmaking?

Come join other changemakers, educators and makers as we draw on our experiences in understanding our biases, identifying conflicts of interests to build the Decisionmaking Chatbot. Over the course of 7 weeks, we will be using an iterative process to build the chatbot through:
-Mapping out the conversations we want to have between the user -and the chatbot
-Researching additional resources and topic areas for the conversations
-Building the bot using publicly available software such as Dexter
-Testing the bot with diverse segments of the public
-Iterating and refining the box

*For this week, we will be starting to explore Dexter, so please bring your laptop! 

We will be debuting the chatbot at MakerFaire 2017 (22-23 July), so there will be a big audience for its launch! Come and be part of the effort to help each other be better critical thinkers. 

==

Our meeting dates are currently:
26 May
2 June
9 June
16 June
30 June
14 July 
21 July
Each session builds on previous sessions, so we strongly recommend that join us for as many sessions as possible.

events.name: Learning to plan with deep neural networks
events.description: Solving decision making tasks, such as navigation, often requires complex reasoning. Traditional approaches involve constructing a model of the task and planning. However, constructing accurate models is difficult. Deep neural networks brought unprecedented success in several domains. However, neural networks ignore the underlying structure of planning, and thus cannot scale to complex decision making problems. I will talk about recent research efforts that combine the strength of model-based planning and data based deep learning, such as Value Iteration Networks and QMDP-net. Bio: Peter Karkus, PhD candidate at the National University of Singapore. His research focuses on machine learning for robotics. Peter has done his undergraduate and master studies in Hungary, and lived in South Korea, Japan and the US since then. He has received the prestigious Fulbright scholarship and worked on motion planning at the Carnegie Mellon University before moving to Singapore.
